thread.title: Jeremy Corbyn detached himself from reality with mad 400,000 green job pledge

author: Neil Parish
title: Jeremy Corbyn detached himself from reality with mad 400,000 green job pledge
text:
News opinion Jeremy Corbyn detached himself from reality with mad 400,000 green job pledge Neil Parish MP says the Labour leader pitch for power is based on recycled hot air Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
NEIL PARISH IS THE CONSERVATIVE MP FOR TIVERTON AND HONITON AND HAS BEEN SINCE 2010
With Labour divided over Brexit and antisemitism, you can hardly blame Jeremy Corbyn for wanting to detach himself from reality. And his speech last week did exactly that.
A pledge of 400,000 new green jobs is as mad today as it was in 2009 (when Gordon Brown first announced it). A pitch for power, based on recycled hot air. At least this time, Labour admit these jobs would come from the ‘public purse’.
Of course, government doesn’t have money of its own. This would be your money in higher taxes, higher energy bills, higher borrowing and deferred debt for your children and grandchildren to pay off. But that won’t get a standing ovation in a conference hall. Neil Parish MP
Neither, I think, would building an extra 7,000 wind turbines on land, whilst creating a raft of new taxpayer subsidies for onshore wind and solar. Instead, we believe subsidies should be reduced in line with falling costs and support should help low-carbon technologies to stand on their own two feet, rather than create dependence on public subsidies, which ultimately drive bills up for consumers. Read More Professional animal abusers can no longer sleep easy at night
Whilst, overall, I welcome an increased focus on clean growth and renewable energy, it is the Conservative approach which is already delivering an affordable, cleaner and greener economy.
We are the first Government to commit to leaving the environment in a better state than we found it. And we are making good on that pledge; ratifying the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, meeting our legally binding carbon budgets, cutting plastic waste and quadrupling renewable electricity capacity.
On top of that, the UK now has enough solar to power almost 2.7 million homes, is the most attractive market in the world for investment in offshore wind and we have already carefully invested £52 billion in renewables, nuclear, and Carbon Capture technology since 2010. Read More Effective flood defences should be a vital part of this country’s infrastructure
Whilst Corbyn remains wedded to the idea of reopening Britain’s coal mines, we are taking the UK’s dirtiest fossil fuel out of the equation altogether. In just a few years, the UK will be one of the first developed countries to close all coal-fired power stations where carbon emissions aren't being captured and stored. Neil Parish MP
Indeed, Greenpeace have already come out and said Labour is “lagging behind the government” on plans to tackle a range of issues, including plastic waste and ocean pollution, adding that "we need to see much more action in other crucial areas for Labour to win the title of the greenest major party". I agree. Read More
